articles.headline: Denise Morrison Quits as Campbell Chief, Further Cutting Female C.E.O. Ranks
articles.snippet: With Ms. Morrison’s abrupt departure, there are now 23 women leading S.&P. 500 companies.
articles.abstract: With Ms. Morrison’s abrupt departure, there are now 23 women leading S.&P. 500 companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Denise M. Morrison, weaned on assurances from her father that the future would someday be led by women, yearned for the executive suite years before she occupied it.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu, Claire Cain Miller and David Gelles

articles.headline: Goldman C.E.O. Blankfein Is Likely to Step Down in December
articles.snippet: Lloyd Blankfein’s retirement plans are firming up, and his likely successor, David Solomon, is already laying the groundwork for a new management team.
articles.abstract: Lloyd Blankfein’s retirement plans are firming up, and his likely successor, David Solomon, is already laying the groundwork for a new management team.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new era at Goldman Sachs is taking shape.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly

articles.headline: House Farm Bill Collapses Amid Republican Disarray
articles.snippet: A rebellion from conservative lawmakers sank a vast farm-policy bill on the House floor Friday amid a fight over how to proceed on immigration.
articles.abstract: A rebellion from conservative lawmakers sank a vast farm-policy bill on the House floor Friday amid a fight over how to proceed on immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The factional rancor threatening Republicans heading into the midterm elections this fall erupted into the open on Friday when a slugfest among moderates, hard-line conservatives and House leaders over immigration and welfare policy sank the party’s multiyear farm bill.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Tech Hit This Small Town Hard. Now, Locals Hope It Will Fuel a Revival.
articles.snippet: Holywell, a town in Wales with dozens of local retailers, has struggled with the impacts of online shopping. It is applying technology to try and keep its shops open.
articles.abstract: Holywell, a town in Wales with dozens of local retailers, has struggled with the impacts of online shopping. It is applying technology to try and keep its shops open.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLYWELL, Wales — Officials in this Welsh town will soon install free Wi-Fi along their lone shopping street. They are erecting the first electric car chargers in the area. And this past winter, small businesses began partnering with an American mobile payments system in the hope of getting more people in their stores.
articles.byline: By Prashant S. Rao

articles.headline: Booming Savannah Port Sees Trade Tensions as Just a Hiccup
articles.snippet: At the nation’s fourth-busiest gateway, local confidence over its potential outweighs any anxiety over the threat of tariffs.
articles.abstract: At the nation’s fourth-busiest gateway, local confidence over its potential outweighs any anxiety over the threat of tariffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Ga. — Savannah’s ocean ports feature skyscraping silver cranes that stand at attention on the water’s edge. Container ships stretch the length of four football fields, with 40-foot containers stacked behind them like multicolored Lego bricks.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: F.B.I. Used Informant to Investigate Russia Ties to Campaign, Not to Spy, as Trump Claims
articles.snippet: The informant made contact in the summer of 2016 with Trump campaign advisers who were already under scrutiny for ties to Russia.
articles.abstract: The informant made contact in the summer of 2016 with Trump campaign advisers who were already under scrutiny for ties to Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump accused the F.B.I. on Friday, without evidence, of sending a spy to secretly infiltrate his 2016 campaign “for political purposes” even before the bureau had any inkling of the “phony Russia hoax.”
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman, Mark Mazzetti and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: ‘Please Pray’: Santa Fe Is a Town That Has Long Found Comfort in Faith
articles.snippet: For many in Santa Fe, the past year has drawn on all the reserves of faith they have. First, Hurricane Harvey. And then Friday’s mass shooting.
articles.abstract: For many in Santa Fe, the past year has drawn on all the reserves of faith they have. First, Hurricane Harvey. And then Friday’s mass shooting.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are praying today in Santa Fe, Tex. They often are, but after Friday, the need feels bottomless. Even before the gunman stopped shooting, even before the headlines reported tragedy, even before they knew it was 10 dead at the high school in the middle of town, a plea hurried out from person to person, screen to screen.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Amy Harmon

articles.headline: Hundreds of Apps Can Empower Stalkers to Track Their Victims
articles.snippet: Widely available services offer a range of spying abilities, including tracking people’s phones and harvesting their texts. As survivors seek help, the legal and technical hurdles are many.
articles.abstract: Widely available services offer a range of spying abilities, including tracking people’s phones and harvesting their texts. As survivors seek help, the legal and technical hurdles are many.
articles.lead_paragraph: KidGuard is a phone app that markets itself as a tool for keeping tabs on children. But it has also promoted its surveillance for other purposes and run blog posts with headlines like “How to Read Deleted Texts on Your Lover’s Phone.”
articles.byline: By Jennifer Valentino-DeVries

articles.headline: As Prince Harry and Meghan Markle Wed, a New Era Dawns
articles.snippet: An extraordinary ceremony with strong elements of African-American culture showed the couple’s determination to bring Britain’s royal family into the modern world.
articles.abstract: An extraordinary ceremony with strong elements of African-American culture showed the couple’s determination to bring Britain’s royal family into the modern world.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINDSOR, England — A thousand-year-old English castle echoed with the exhortations of an African-American bishop and a gospel choir on Saturday, as Prince Harry wed Meghan Markle, an American actress, nudging the British royal family into a new era.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Germany Acts to Tame Facebook, Learning From Its Own History of Hate
articles.snippet: A country taps its past as it leads the way on one of the most pressing issues facing modern democracies: how to regulate the world’s biggest social network.
articles.abstract: A country taps its past as it leads the way on one of the most pressing issues facing modern democracies: how to regulate the world’s biggest social network.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Security is tight at this brick building on the western edge of Berlin. Inside, a sign warns: “Everybody without a badge is a potential spy!”
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Trump Jr. and Other Aides Met With Gulf Emissary Offering Help to Win Election
articles.snippet: The Trump Tower meeting and follow-ups are the first indication that countries beyond Russia may have offered help to the Trump campaign.
articles.abstract: The Trump Tower meeting and follow-ups are the first indication that countries beyond Russia may have offered help to the Trump campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three months before the 2016 election, a small group gathered at Trump Tower to meet with Donald Trump Jr., the president’s eldest son. One was an Israeli specialist in social media manipulation. Another was an emissary for two wealthy Arab princes. The third was a Republican donor with a controversial past in the Middle East as a private security contractor.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Israel and Evangelicals: New U.S. Embassy Signals a Growing Alliance
articles.snippet: The opening of the U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem marks the increasing importance of conservative Christians to Israel, at the risk of upsetting American Jews.
articles.abstract: The opening of the U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem marks the increasing importance of conservative Christians to Israel, at the risk of upsetting American Jews.
articles.lead_paragraph: A night after the dedication of the new United States Embassy in Jerusalem, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel convened American evangelicals to plan their next steps.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Elizabeth Dias and David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: New Reality for High School Students: Calculating the Risk of Getting Shot
articles.snippet: Students in an age of school shootings routinely consider the safety of their classrooms, running scenarios about how likely they are to get shot.
articles.abstract: Students in an age of school shootings routinely consider the safety of their classrooms, running scenarios about how likely they are to get shot.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just hours after a gunman killed 10 people at a Texas high school, two students 1,000 miles away worried about the safety of their usual seats in the school cafeteria.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch, Amy Harmon and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: Trump Demands Inquiry Into Whether Justice Dept. ‘Infiltrated or Surveilled’ His Campaign
articles.snippet: Legal experts said President Trump’s promise of intervention had little precedent, and could force a clash between the sitting president and his Justice Department.
articles.abstract: Legal experts said President Trump’s promise of intervention had little precedent, and could force a clash between the sitting president and his Justice Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Sunday demanded that the Justice Department investigate whether the department or the F.B.I. “infiltrated or surveilled” his campaign at the behest of the Obama administration, following through on his frequent threats to intervene in the special counsel inquiry as he targets those he views as political enemies.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Banks Adopt Military-Style Tactics to Fight Cybercrime
articles.snippet: Financial institutions are using military tools and techniques, like “fusion centers” and combat drills, to battle cybercrime.
articles.abstract: Financial institutions are using military tools and techniques, like “fusion centers” and combat drills, to battle cybercrime.
articles.lead_paragraph: O’FALLON, Mo. — In a windowless bunker here, a wall of monitors tracked incoming attacks — 267,322 in the last 24 hours, according to one hovering dial, or about three every second — as a dozen analysts stared at screens filled with snippets of computer code.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Mueller Hopes Obstruction Inquiry Into Trump May Wrap Up by Sept. 1, Giuliani Says
articles.snippet: Mr. Giuliani sought to make the case that a longer timeline for that aspect of the Russia investigation would hurt Republicans in the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: Mr. Giuliani sought to make the case that a longer timeline for that aspect of the Russia investigation would hurt Republicans in the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel hopes to finish by Sept. 1 the investigation into whether President Trump obstructed the Russia inquiry, according to the president’s lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani, who said on Sunday that waiting any longer would risk improperly influencing voters in November’s midterm elections.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank’s Problems Threaten a Star Banker
articles.snippet: Paul Achleitner made Goldman Sachs a force in Frankfurt and shook up corporate Germany. But he is increasingly blamed for problems at Deutsche Bank.
articles.abstract: Paul Achleitner made Goldman Sachs a force in Frankfurt and shook up corporate Germany. But he is increasingly blamed for problems at Deutsche Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Ever since he was a 38-year-old Goldman Sachs executive helping to auction off bankrupt East German factories, Paul Achleitner has been known as a relentless modernizer shaking up Germany’s sleepy corporate world.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: As Disney Moves Forward With Fox, Comcast Continues Plotting
articles.snippet: The Walt Disney Company struck a deal in December to buy most of 21st Century Fox, but Comcast, which has pursued Fox in the past, thinks it has another opening.
articles.abstract: The Walt Disney Company struck a deal in December to buy most of 21st Century Fox, but Comcast, which has pursued Fox in the past, thinks it has another opening.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Comcast confirmed in a statement that it was in the “advanced stages of preparing”  its own bid for the 21st Century Fox assets that Walt Disney has agreed to buy.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Anti-Gun Backlash From School Shooting? Probably Not in Texas
articles.snippet: Activism after the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., led to the most successful push for gun control in decades in the state. Few expect the same in Texas.
articles.abstract: Activism after the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., led to the most successful push for gun control in decades in the state. Few expect the same in Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, Tex. — One mile from the scene of the shooting that left 10 people dead at her school, Monica Bracknell, a senior at Santa Fe High School, approached Texas Gov. Greg Abbott in the lobby of Arcadia First Baptist Church here Sunday morning.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Jack Healy and Dave Montgomery

articles.headline: Trump Grappling With Risks of Proceeding With North Korea Meeting
articles.snippet: President Trump was surprised and angered by a statement issued by the North’s chief nuclear negotiator, who declared that the country would not swap its nuclear weapons capability for economic aid.
articles.abstract: President Trump was surprised and angered by a statement issued by the North’s chief nuclear negotiator, who declared that the country would not swap its nuclear weapons capability for economic aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, increasingly concerned that his summit meeting in Singapore next month with North Korea’s leader could turn into a political embarrassment, has begun pressing his aides and allies about whether he should take the risk of proceeding with a historic meeting that he had leapt into accepting, according to administration and foreign officials.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Hillary and Bill Clinton Go Separate Ways for 2018 Midterm Elections
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton plans to endorse Andrew M. Cuomo for governor of New York this week. But elsewhere on the 2018 campaign trail, she and Mr. Clinton are not always welcome.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton plans to endorse Andrew M. Cuomo for governor of New York this week. But elsewhere on the 2018 campaign trail, she and Mr. Clinton are not always welcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years they dominated the party, brandishing their powerful financial network and global fame to pick favorites for primary elections and lift Democrats even in deep-red states. They were viewed as a joint entity, with a shared name that was the most powerful brand in Democratic politics: the Clintons.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Supreme Court Upholds Workplace Arbitration Contracts Barring Class Actions
articles.snippet: The vote was 5 to 4, with the court’s more conservative justices in the majority. The court’s decision could affect some 25 million employment contracts.
articles.abstract: The vote was 5 to 4, with the court’s more conservative justices in the majority. The court’s decision could affect some 25 million employment contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that companies can use arbitration clauses in employment contracts to prohibit workers from banding together to take legal action over workplace issues.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Trump’s Charm and Threats May Not Be Working on China. Here’s Why.
articles.snippet: President Trump threatened tariffs on $150 billion in goods, then tried conciliation. Beijing’s response either way: Rebuff the offers and avoid specific pledges.
articles.abstract: President Trump threatened tariffs on $150 billion in goods, then tried conciliation. Beijing’s response either way: Rebuff the offers and avoid specific pledges.
articles.lead_paragraph: China has called President Trump’s bluff.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher
